newsitem.title: INDIA: Muted Indian market response to Chidambaram sops.
newsitem.headline: Muted Indian market response to Chidambaram sops.

text.p: Stock brokers and traders in Indian commercial hub of Bombay were disappointed by the measly incentives announced by the finance minister on Friday.
"If these are the only incentives, the market will take a dive next week," said broker Ramesh Damani, a member of the Bombay Stock Exchange.
Finance Minister P. Chidambaram told parliament that investments in mutual funds will be exempted from capital gains tax and foreign funds can float dedicated debt funds.
"The pace is slow, terribly slow but the direction is right," said an analyst at a foreign brokerage.
"He's taken some policy decisions which are positive," the analyst said, adding that international investors would be encouraged to invest in India's fledgling debt market.
Chidambaram said the ceiling on bank loans against shares would be doubled to 1.0 million rupees.
He also raised the ceiling on tax spared dividend and interest incomes to 15,000 rupees from 13,000 rupees.
Analysts said the statement had nothing to boost the sluggish stock markets.
"There's nothing to jump start the markets in the short-term," one analyst at a foreign broking firm said.
He said the sops would give domestic mutual funds a "level playing field".
Currently, foreign mutual funds based in Mauritius are exempted from the taxes, one analyst said.
Other traders said the exemption will have no immediate impact on the market because many mutual funds were quoted at huge discounts to their face value.
Chidambaram will make a more detailed statement next week when he will address tax proposals before the finance bill is passed by parliament.

Some analysts are expecting the dilution of a controversial 12.9 percent minimum alternate tax (MAT) on company profits but many brokers feel Chidambaram is unlikely to tamper with the tax proposals announced in July's budget.
